fullText: Spamalot, first seen on Broadway in 2005, is back—and the good news is the really good silly bits of this parody of Arthurian legend are just as good-silly as they always were. But the bits that felt dated have only become more dated; one a song about Jews running Broadway at this moment sounds not just dated but also weird in this politically vexed moment (especially with a huge, glittering Star of David), the other is a rousing hymn to gay pride for Sir Lancelot (Taran Killam), which is discordantly beamed in from another era.

keyPhrases.quote: the really good silly bits of this parody of Arthurian legend are just as good-silly as they always were
the bits that felt dated have only become more dated
sounds not just dated but also weird in this politically vexed moment

llmScore.reasoning: Claude: The review acknowledges the show's enduring comedic strengths but expresses significant concern about dated material that feels problematic in the current political climate, creating a mixed but slightly negative overall impression. | GPT-4o-mini: The review highlights some enduring humor but emphasizes that many elements feel increasingly outdated, leading to a mixed recommendation.

bwwExcerpt: Spamalot’s expertly written and performed silliness is endless, beguiling, and winning, and so well-done that—despite the gay and Jewish clunkers of songs—the musical remains a daffy, rollicking night out. The final confetti canon—a Broadway staple, and often a last desperate roll of the dice in any show—here feels absolutely perfect.
